headline: Deutsche Börse Shareholders Approve London Stock Exchange Merger
abstract: At least 60 percent of the German stock exchange operator’s outstanding shares were pledged in support of the transaction.

headline: Jewish Settlers, Attacked, Needed Help. A Palestinian Doctor Didn’t Hesitate.
abstract: Dr. Ali Shroukh’s lifesaving efforts on a West Bank road have been hailed in Israel as inspirational in the face of months of increasing conflict.

headline: Keeping Hackers From Grabbing Your Twitter Account
abstract: Password-theft, phishing and unsecured apps can lead to a compromised Twitter account, but you can shore up your defenses.

headline: Finding a Hard Drive in Just the Right Size
abstract: Many new lightweight laptops come with solid-state drives that work faster but store less, but explore your options when buying a new machine.

headline: Facebook to Add ‘Secret Conversations’ to Messenger App
abstract: The app has long taken a back seat to the social media giant’s WhatsApp, but Facebook hopes the service will attract a global audience.

headline: A Danish Wind Turbine Maker Harnesses Data in a Push to Stay Ahead
abstract: Vestas was in a precarious position in 2012, but it is now a market leader, thanks in large part to its focus on data and mathematics.

headline: A New Disney Princesa Carries Responsibilities Beyond Her Kingdom
abstract: Disney has created its first Latina princess, Elena, who will have her debut on the Disney Channel this month.

headline: Factional Fighting Breaks Out in South Sudan’s Capital
abstract: Gunfire broke out for a second straight day on Friday, threatening a truce just days before the country’s independence anniversary.

headline: Obama Rebukes Poland’s Right-Wing Government
abstract: President Obama expressed concern over the Polish government’s constitutional crisis as a NATO summit meeting began in Warsaw.

headline: A Portrait of the Millennial Generation Changing China
abstract: Alec Ash, author of “Wish Lanterns: Young Lives in New China,” views this generation as the “thin end of a wedge” that is slowly opening Chinese society.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Conservatives Decide a Woman Should Lead Britain
abstract: Tory lawmakers have chosen Theresa May and Andrea Leadsom as finalists who will go before the party’s rank-and-file members to become its next leader, as well as prime minister.

headline: For China, a Missile Defense System in South Korea Spells a Failed Courtship
abstract: South Korea showed that it was embracing its alliance with Washington more than ever, and that it would rely less on China to keep North Korea at bay.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: May and Leadsom Face Off to Become Prime Minister
abstract: The next premier will be a woman, consumer confidence has tanked and the trans-Atlantic alliance may be facing its most important moment since the Cold War.

headline: A Central Conflict of 21st-Century Politics: Who Belongs?
abstract: Michael Ignatieff, a former party leader in Canada, describes tensions between those who see immigration as a universal right, and those who regard it as a limited gift.

headline: Dolan Family Repurchases Newsday
abstract: Only two weeks after handing the paper to Altice in a deal for Cablevision, Newsday is again part of the Dolan family holdings.

headline: Deutsche Bank Pulls Back from Deals in Coal Mining Sector
abstract: Investment bankers leave as Deutsche joins other banks in cutting financing to a beaten-down industry that has attracted environmentalists’ scorn.

headline: A Mayor Fluent in Twitter Embodies a New Canadian Diversity
abstract: Naheed Nenshi, the groundbreaking Muslim mayor of Calgary, is known for his acid Twitter retorts and for revitalizing the city. His faith rarely comes up.

headline: Maybe North Korea’s Nuclear Goals Are More Serious Than Once Thought
abstract: The country’s weapons programs have long been understood as meant for propaganda, not military, purposes. That view might be dangerously wrong.

headline: For Effective Brain Fitness, Do More Than Play Simple Games
abstract: The theory of a more holistic approach is that the brain thrives on continuous stimulation, which can include exercising, laughing and socializing.

headline: Museum Showcases the ‘Art’ of Animal Excrement
abstract: “People are disgusted by poo, but there’s also this fascination with it,” said an artist who helped create a one-room exhibit at the Isle of Wight Zoo.

headline: Eggs That Clear the Cages, but Maybe Not the Conscience
abstract: The country’s biggest food companies are embracing cage-free eggs, but hens raised in aviaries may not be much healthier than their caged counterparts.
